DOC.HEAD: More U.S. Wheat for Soviets
DOC.TEXT: The Soviet Union will be able to buy an additional 2 million metric tons of U.S. wheat at subsidized prices, the Agriculture Department said Tuesday. Undersecretary Richard T. Crowder said the wheat will be made available under the department's Export Enhancement Program, or EEP. The new amount is in addition to 14,200 tons Moscow had remaining under a previous allocation announced last May 2. The Soviet Union is committed to buy minimum quantities of wheat and corn under a long-term grain agreement, which began its seventh year on Oct. 1 and will expire Dec. 31, 1990. Moscow has bought about 800,000 tons of wheat for delivery in 1989-90, according to USDA records. Nearly 11 million tons of corn have been sold for 1989-90 delivery, along with soybeans and soybean meal. In 1988-89, the sixth period under the agreement, the Soviet Union bought about 5.4 million tons of wheat and more than 16.3 million tons of corn, plus soybeans, soybean meal and grain sorghums. A metric ton is about 2,205 pounds and is equal to 36.7 bushels of wheat. The EEP arrangement allows private exporters to sell wheat and other designated commodities to specified countries at reduced prices in order to meet foreign competition. The exporters then collect free government surpluses of grain or other products as bonuses, or subsidies. Since EEP began in 1985, more than $2.6 billion in subsidies has been paid to exporters to ship a variety of commodities to overseas customers. As of Nov. 30, sales totaled 87.2 million tons of grain, including 64.4 million tons of wheat. The Soviet Union, as the largest EEP beneficiary, has bought more than 17.5 million tons of wheat. China is second at 13.2 million tons of wheat, plus 185 head of cattle.
